introduction: In this video, we will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of SQL and NoSQL databases. SQL databases are structured, relational, and vertically scalable, while NoSQL databases are flexible, simpler to set up, and horizontally scalable. We will also cover eventual consistency and distributed databases in NoSQL systems.

sections.title: Section 1: SQL Databases
content: SQL databases are structured and relational, allowing for easy querying on relationships between data.
Data is well-structured and potential errors are reduced due to schema requirements.
SQL transactions are atomic, consistent, isolated, and durable (ACID), ensuring data integrity.
SQL databases can be difficult to scale horizontally due to their relational nature.

sections.title: Section 2: NoSQL Databases
content: NoSQL databases are more flexible and simpler to set up compared to SQL databases.
They are better at handling unstructured data and can shard data across different data stores.
Eventual consistency is a tradeoff in distributed NoSQL systems, resulting in a small delay before updates propagate to other replicas.
Single shard NoSQL databases can be strongly consistent, but to take advantage of scalability benefits, they should be set up as distributed clusters.
